title: Transgressions of compartment boundaries and cell reprogramming during regeneration in <italic>Drosophila</italic>
abstract: Animals have developed mechanisms to reconstruct lost or damaged tissues. To regenerate those tissues the cells implicated have to undergo developmental reprogramming. The imaginal discs of <italic>Drosophila</italic> are subdivided into distinct compartments, which derive from different genetic programs. This feature makes them a convenient system to study reprogramming during regeneration. We find that massive damage inflicted to the posterior or the dorsal compartment of the wing disc causes a transient breakdown of compartment boundaries, which are quickly reconstructed. The cells involved in the reconstruction often modify their original identity, visualized by changes in the expression of developmental genes like <italic>engrailed</italic> or <italic>cubitus interruptus</italic>. This reprogramming is mediated by up regulation of the JNK pathway and transient debilitation of the epigenetic control mechanism. Our results also show that the local developmental context plays a role in the acquisition of new cell identities: cells expressing <italic>engrailed</italic> induce <italic>engrailed</italic> expression in neighbor cells.
